google.process:
Direct onsite because I interviewed in the past and did well that time. From the time I sent my resume to interview day: 2 weeks. From interview day to offer over the phone: 2 weeks.

The syllabus for the interviews is very clear and simple:
1) Dynamic Programming
2) Super recursion (permutation, combination,...2^n, m^n, n!...etc. type of program. (NP hard, NP programs)
3) Probability related programs
4) Graphs: BFS/DFS are usually enough
5) All basic data structures from Arrays/Lists to circular queues, BSTs, Hash tables, B-Trees, and Red-Black trees, and all basic algorithms like sorting, binary search, median,...
6) Problem solving ability at a level similar to TopCoder Division 1, 250 points. If you can consistently solve these, then you are almost sure to get in with 2-weeks brush up.
7) Review all old interview questions in Glassdoor to get a feel. If you can solve 95% of them at home (including coding them up quickly and testing them out in a debugger + editor setup), you are in good shape.
8) Practice coding--write often and write a lot. If you can think of a solution, you should be able to code it easily...without much thought.
9) Very good to have for design interview: distributed systems knowledge and practical experience. 
10) Good understanding of basic discrete math, computer architecture, basic math.
11) Coursera courses and assignments give a lot of what you need to know.
12) Note that all the above except the first 2 are useful in "real life" programming too! 

Interview 1:
Graph related question and super recursion

Interview 2:
Design discussion involving a distributed system with writes/reads going on at different sites in parallel.

Interview 3:
Array and Tree related questions

Interview 4:
Designing a simple class to do something. Not hard, but not easy either. You need to know basic data structures very well to consider different designs and trade-offs.

Interview 5:
Dynamic programming, 
Computer architecture and low level perf. enhancement question which requires knowledge of Trees, binary search, etc.

At the end, I wasn't tired and rather enjoyed the discussions. I think the key was long term preparation and time spent doing topcoder for several years (on and off as I enjoy solving the problems). 

Conclusion: "It's not the best who win the race; it's the best prepared who win it."
questions: Give as many ways as you can delete a file named "-f"
Comment vendriez-vous notre produit Ã  un certain type de client?
What type of motor starters do you recommend and why

amazon.process:
I will split this review into 2 sections pertaining to my preparation process and interview process.

PREPARATION:
First, I prepared by reaching out to my OCM (Office of Career Management) part of my MBA program. They reached out to the alumni that worked in the specific job and connected me with them. This was essential to my process and helped me a lot as it helped me get an inside look of the interviewers thought process before the interview.
I then prepared a document to save and answer any interview question that I could find from resources, such as Glass Door, pertaining to typical Amazon behavioral interview questions.
I also watched interview related YouTube videos that helped me prepare. Since Amazon is such a large company and hires a lot of people, there are a lot of these videos available. There are a few YouTube channels dedicated to the Amazon hiring process and interview preparation.
I then reviewed the leadership principles and familiarized myself with them.  I paired behavioral questions with these principles, and related them to my experience via the STAR format.
One thing I HIGHLY suggest is practicing your responses, making them fluid and natural as part of a normal conversation. Record yourself, practice in the mirror, etc. Also, do NOT simply write down your responses and read them to the interviewer. This will get you negative points, and possibly cause them to pass on you.

INTERVIEW:
Total time: 3 HR, 15 Min. 
4 interview, 45 min long, 15 min. break after 2nd interview.
Amazon is moving towards online interview process. There are not doing as much on-campus interviews or flying candidates out to the location for in-person interviews.
My Amazon interview was a total of FOUR interviews. Each of these interviews lasted for 45 minutes. Amazon will try to do all 4 of these interviews within 1 day. 
Be prepared to commit to the interview date, and be prepared for it to take the better half of the day.
Each interviewer was punctual and direct. They gave a quick introduction of themselves, asked for a quick introduction of myself, and then quickly moved into behavioral type questioning.
Preparing ahead of time is essential. I HIGHLY recommend the STAR format. Amazon is very results driven. Don't focus on non-essential information. Focus on actions and results.
Each interviewer will ask you for more details and challenge you during the interview. Be prepared to be challenged and have those answers ready if possible.
2 of the interviewers I had gave me hypothetical questions to get to know my thought process better and to learn what my managerial style is like.

All in all, it was a great experience. If you make it to this round of interview, you will most likely do well. Amazon is selective in their candidates, and seek out very qualified individuals for positions like this. You will more than likely enjoy this interview. My preparation helped me a great deal. Do not take the preparation lightly. 

Finally, the questions that I included were part of my preparation and found online. They were also asked by the interviewer. Not all of the questions asked are included.
questions: Why Amazon?
Tell me about a time when you had to leave a task unfinished.
Tell me about a time when you gave a simple solution to a complex problem.
Tell me about a time when you invented something.
Tell me about a time when you had to work with incomplete data or information.
Tell me about a time when you influenced a change by only asking questions.
Tell me about a time when you solved a problem through just superior knowledge or observation.
Tell me about your proudest professional achievement.
Tell me about a time when you took a calculated risk.
Tell me about a time when you had to work with limited time or resources.
Give me two examples of when you did more than what was required in any job experience.
Tell me about an unpopular decision of yours.

Round 1 - Online Coding Round : There were 2 coding question and I was able to solve both of them.
1st question was related to heap and other BFS. Both were Medium level questions.

Got an email from the recruiter next day(16th Feb, 2021) that they will schedule four interview rounds and they will call me soon to discuss.
They had given me 1 month of preparation time and scheduled interview on end of March. I don't know they give this much amount of time for
preparation to others or not.

The 3 sections of the assessment

Coding challenge (2 scenarios) and Coding approach (elaborate why you code the way you do) - 105 minutes
Work style survey - 15 minutes
Feedback survey - 5 minutes

Round 2 - Coding Round with SDE2 (10:00 AM):
Interview started with the introduction of the interviewer and then he asked me to tell about myself. (~6 mins)
Then some basic OS question : Process and thread. Difference between them and how they work. (~5 mins)
Coding Question : No. of Islands. This is standard leetcode question asked by Amazon. (~ 20 mins)
I already solved this question earlier so I knew the approach as well. I started with a brute force solution and then moved to the optimized approach.
I was asked to write the optimized solution in production level code and asked me assume the best cases as well.
Atlast I was asked to dry run the code and explain the code line by line and write the time complexity and space complexity.
Interviewer was okay with my solution.

Next question was related to string and had to find longest substring of size K. I gave the brute force solution but was not able to come up with the optimized
solution. (~15 mins)
He told me to write the brute force solution and do the code walk through. In the end he told me that I was missing one base case in my solution.
I tried to find that missing test case but I was not able to find it. (I think this is the reason I was rejected).
In the next ~5-6 mins he asked me some LP's and I was able to answer them based on my experience.

Round 3 - Coding Round with SDE2 (11:30 AM):
2 Coding questions:

Find the longest substring without repetiting character (https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-substring-without-repeating-characters/)

Kth Largest Element in an Array (https://leetcode.com/problems/kth-largest-element-in-an-array/submissions/)
Able to solve both questions and interviewer was satisfied.

In the end I was asked 2 LP. I really felt good after this round as I was able to answer all the questions.

I thought I am done for today but around 2:00 Pm I got a call from the recruiter that he is scheduling a managerial coding round at 3:00 PM.
I told him that I will be available for the round.

Round 4 - Managerial coding round with 2 SDM's
Quick intro about the Managers and my intro. (~7-8 mins)
2 LPs (~6-7mins)
So far so good.
Coding Question :

Word Search https://leetcode.com/problems/word-search/ (~ 20 mins)
Able to solve and explain the approach to the interviewer.
Wrote the time complexity and space complexity as well in the end)
Around 15 mins left.

Calculate the angle between hour hand and minute hand
I told him my approach but was not able to come up with the correct answer. He mentioned I am going in the right direction and told me to write the
code for my approach. As I had not came up with the correct logic I was not able to think how to code it. I wrote pseudocode and explained it.
(This can be reason for my rejection)
In the end they asked me if I had any question.
All the interviewers were very friendly and guided me whenever I stucked.

Next day I got a rejection mail. I didn't thought that I will be rejected. I was able to solve almost all coding questions. I prepared all the LP's
based on my experience and was confident in all interviews.

I have written the reasons that may led my rejection. Hopefully this will help other candidates while preparing. I wish you luck.

Sobre una situacion dificil en mi trabajo y como la supere.

meta.process:
Meta Interview Process (Software Engineer)
ð 1. Application & Recruiter Screen
You apply directly or get referred.

A recruiter reaches out to discuss:

Your background and resume.

Role fit and level (IC3, IC4, IC5, etc.).

Timeline and next steps.

ð§  2. Online Assessment / Technical Phone Screens
Depending on level and role, youâll face:

ð¹ (A) Online Coding Assessment (often for interns/new grads)
HackerRank-style test (2-3 problems).

Focus on data structures, algorithms, edge cases, and efficiency.

ð¹ (B) Technical Phone Interview(s) (1â2 rounds)
45-minute coding interview via CoderPad or Meta's internal tool.

Solve 1â2 Leetcode-style problems live.

Expect:

Strings, Trees, Graphs, Dynamic Programming, etc.

Follow-up questions and optimizations.

Clean code, communication, and test cases.

nvidia.process:
The interviewer asked me to open a project and start writing TypeScript, JavaScript, and CSS files to build a React app. Some of the main components were already there, but I had to manage the entire app logic and figure out how to structure and build the whole mini application on the spot. Honestly, it felt a bit overwhelming and unexpectedâespecially since I had focused my preparation on algorithm and coding questions, which are more common in interviews.

What made it more difficult was that the interviewer seemed distracted and busy with something else during the session. It didnât really feel like a respectful or supportive environment for the candidate, which was disappointing.

openai.process:
Applied to a role after being referred by a current employee of the company and former colleague of mine. Process involved an initial screening with a recruiter, a technical screening with an engineer, and two more full length interviews on coding and systems design. Beyond that I believe there were two more interviews with hiring managers to be had, but I did not make it that far. 

After my last two interviews I sent an email to the recruiter who I had been working with thanking the team for their time and reiterating my interest in the position, to which I received no reply. After 5 days of not hearing anything, I sent another follow up email to check in and again did not get a response. At this point Iâm just wanting to hear any news, good or otherwise and decide to re-comb through my inbox by hand. Sure enough, there was an email in my junk box that I had missed because it came from a third-party domain. It appeared to be an automated message, which stated that they were not moving forward with my application.

Disappointed but wanting to keep the door open, I sent one last email thanking them again, asking for feedback, and letting them know I would love to still be considered for other roles future. Again, no response. 

While I certainly donât expect a response after every job application, I do think itâs reasonable to expect one after investing hours of my personal time into preparing for and performing several rounds of interviews, I found the impersonal, automated, rejection notice and ghosting by the recruiter highly unprofessional and disrespectful of my time as a candidate. Iâd have serious doubts about interviewing here again after my experience.
questions: Design an API for an in-memory database.

Your background?
How do you prioritize competing tasks?
Tell me more about yourself and your experience
LC Med. Nothing Chat GPT can't solve. But I obviously didn't use it, otherwise I'd have passed.

Asked to go through my experience.

Common / well known system design question; for coding, not leetcode style, but more like implementing a feature step by step.
I found this could be helpful:
https://www.sx-studio.com/openai-sde-interview/

HR round - 30min talk about resume, why openai and why this role?
One day later got the phone interview invitation
2 60min sessions back to back: 1 coding, 1 system design
What your current tech stack?

The full loop included four structured interviews:

	1.	Project Retrospective / Technical Deep Dive
I was asked to prepare a slide deck walking through a complex technical program I had led.

The focus seems ob decision-making, stakeholder alignment, and managing the program The interviewer expected clear articulation of impact, technical structure, and mechanisms.

	2.	Cross-Functional Collaboration

This was a STAR-format interview focused on how Iâve worked across diverse teams. I was asked about aligning conflicting priorities, translating between technical and non-technical teams, and managing through ambiguity. The discussion leaned toward how collaboration approaches.

	3.	TPM Process Design

This was a scenario-based discussion. I was given a high-level challenge â e.g., launching a new model or product under safety constraints and tight timelines â and asked how I would manage and structure process.

The interviewer looked for structured thinking, stakeholder mapping, risk identification, and how I would design scalableo design processes.

	4.	Hiring Manager / Values

This round was focused on working style, values, and motivation. I was asked about how I navigate ambiguity, what kind of team culture I thrive in, and what drives to want to join openAI.
Why this team? Why this type of role specifically?
What is your background, what brings you to us
Implement a chat feature in an existing application
How would you design a enforce to usage limits

Design SQL, in memory DB in language of choice
How would u improve the product
multi part coding question and also multi part system design
If you could redesign a part of this place what would you change?
about my work experience doing model distillation

pinterest.process:
Recruiter reached out.
First was the coding round.
Then there was virtual onsite round.

I was interviewing for an intermediate level and for the virtual onsite round all the three interviewers who asked me coding questions were intermediate level with fewer years of experience than me. That is a really bad way of hiring by these companies because a rather Junior interviewer just sits there without guiding you properly, and can not assess your true experience level. 

At the end, I received an email from a different recruiter I hadn't met during process telling me "it was nice to meet you" and giving me the rejection news and telling me they regret they can not give in depth feedback. It felt very impersonal for me as a candidate who made it to the last stage of interview process.
questions: Tell us about your current position, what does your day to day look like
I got an email and they set up an online interview. First step was coding interview. It was online. Two medium to hard Leetcode problems. one question was sorting.

tesla.process: I applied for the team that was working on Optimus. The first round was resume review. We had a standard discussion on projects and why you want to join. The next round was a coding interview in C++. The question given in the coding interview was very vague and I was asked to choose everything for myself when I asked for clarity.
questions: More of an introduction, what I was looking for, and experience.
Does a hotdog split lengthwise or widthwise, why?
Asked statistics questions about battery pack failure analysis
Tell me about a time you had to use data to influence a decision made by senior leadership. What was your approach and what was the result?
Tell me about your background
All process under NDA. Cant be disclosed

Standard interview questions like "what was a challenge you were able to overcome" or "how did you handle a disagreement with a superior". Case study questions were extremely detailed, expect deep follow up in 1:1s following presentation
Why interested in being a TPM over a cell engineering role?

The final interview consisted of 3 different people focusing on certain aspects - UX, Tech, PM skills 

But all basic behavioral questions, so focus on all these aspects in your answers

What's the principal stress and strain?
Some hardware related questions like Power system and LabView.

netflix.process:
I applied online. The job was advertised as a remote position and Iâm based in NYC. I told the recruiter I already had an offer from another company and asked if she could schedule other interviews prematurely. She asked me for the dates I was available and I gave dates for next week and also said the weekend would work if thatâs possible (and given Netflixâs supposed culture of ppl with high talent and ambition and genuine fostering of talent I thought maybe that would be reasonable). The recruiter instead mocked me for even raising that as a possibility and said âwhat kind of culture would Netflix have if we made people work weekendsâ even though I didnât imply they should be making people work weekends (if anything I was thinking people would volunteer since they love their jobsâhow crazy of me).

The first interview went really well. The engineer was very senior and quizzed me on small things ranging from code quality to problem solving / code design.

The next few rounds consisted of leetcode style and system design. the system design was very thorough.

At the end i received an offer on a Friday. They said it would have to be in person actually. I said yes to the offer and then on Monday said i can't accept if i have to relocate to California because of my girlfriend / I grew up in NYC. The manager said he was indifferent to me working from NYC and it was up to the project management committee. I was informed a few days later I was banned from ever applying to Netflix because I rescinded an offer and that showed I was not honest / candid, which is one of their values. This makes no sense as I told the manager there might be issues if I have to move to the bay area because of my girlfriend and that I'd really appreciate being able to work in NYC as the position I applied for advertised. When I accepted the offer I thought I could maybe do this (as would anyone probably convince themselves), but realized it was the wrong decision and was very candid about this the following Monday. 

HR was extremely critical throughout the process of everything I did. I get that thereâs a culture of being very candid in giving feedback, but this feedback felt very contrived and baseless. Maybe itâs because Iâm a white male and Netflix needs more diversity to score popularity points.
